page.topic: Getting Started With Alpha Anywhere - Build Your First Mobile App
page.description: Follow this step-by-step guide to your first Alpha Anywhere application to run in a mobile web environment.

description.p: In this guide, Getting Started with Alpha Anywhere - Build Your First Mobile App, you will build a mobile application from scratch. You will create the *[ui:MobileAppFramework_Sample_Disconnected_app]* template starting with a blank UX Component. Components are the basic building blocks of any Alpha Anywhere application. For many components in Alpha Anywhere, new components can be created using a template. Templates make building some types of applications faster. You can even create your own templates (watch *[extlink:Grid Templates@http://www.alphasoftware.com/video-library/?v=3070]* for more details.)

figure.title: The mobile app you are building.

description.p: This Guide is broken into three parts: [First Things First - Setting Up Your Workspace], [Part 1 - Building Basic Functionality], and [Part 2 - Creating the Responsive Mobile Layout].
[First Things First] covers creating a new Alpha Anywhere workspace and setting up the data source that will be used in this Guide.
[Part 1] shows you how to use the List Genie to create the bare-bones functionality required to do CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations against a data source.
[Part 2] details how to add the layout elements and navigation controls for creating a responsive mobile layout that will look great on smartphones and tablets.

At the beginning of each lesson, a component may be available for download. The downloadable component contains a snapshot of the mobile app as it would look if you had built the component following the previous lessons. Not all lessons will have a component for download. Specifically, [Part 1] does not have component downloads since this section is a step-by-step guild through setting up the *[ui:List Contol - Quick Setup Genie]*, which cannot be saved mid-setup.

note.p: The components available for download in each lesson *[require a connection string to the Northwind database]*. Follow the instructions in [Lesson 2: Build a Database Connection String] to learn how to setup the Northwind database on your system and create the "Northwind" connection string that the List control requires for communicating with the Northwind database.

group.title: First Things First - Setting Up Your Workspace

section.title: Lesson 1: Create a new Web Project
section.description: To create a new mobile application with Alpha Anywhere, you must create a new workspace. A workspace contains all of the files that your application needs, including files such as UX components, javascript libraries, images, HTML or .a5w pages, or css stylesheets. Let's create a new, blank Alpha Anywhere workspace.

figure.title: A new, blank Alpha Anywhere workspace.

step.description: Launch Alpha Anywhere. Under the *[ui:File]* menu, select *[ui:New Workspace...]* to create a new Alpha Anywhere project.

figure.title: Create a New Workspace from the File menu.

step.description: Create a new directory called "HelloAlpha". This directory is where you will save your project.

figure.title: Create a new directory where your workspace will be saved.

step.description: Navigate inside the "HelloAlpha" directory. Type "HelloAlpha" into the *[ui:File name:]* text box. Click the *[ui:Save]* button to create your new workspace.

figure.title: Naming your workspace.

step.description: When the *[ui:Startup Control Panel]* appears, check the box for *[ui:Open the Web Control Panel when this Workspace is opened.]* You will be creating a mobile application. The Web Control Panel is where all of the resources for a web or mobile application are listed. Click *[ui:OK]* to finish creating your new workspace.

figure.title: Specifying the Web Control Panel should be opened when the Workspace is opened.

section.description: You have created a new, blank Alpha Anywhere workspace. You can now start building your mobile application.

figure.title: A new, blank Alpha Anywhere workspace.

section.title: Lesson 2: Build a Database Connection String
section.description: The mobile application you will be creating will interact with the Northwind database. A Microsoft Access version of the Northwind database ships with Alpha Anywhere. If you prefer to use a different database system, you can follow the instructions below to setup the Northwind database in SQL Server or MySQL. Choose one of the options below -- Acces, SQL Server, or MySQL -- to start creating a Connection String for the Northwind database.

case.title: Build an Access Connection String
case.description: This section guildes you through the process of setting up an Access connection string to the Northwind database. In order to perform CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations on the Access Northwind database that ships with Alpha Anywhere, it must be copied from the installation directory to a directory in which you have read/write access. This is typically the Users directory.

step.description: Locate the *[Northwind.mdb]* Access database. It can be found in the installation directory for Alpha Anywhere inside the MDBFiles directory. EG, *[bold:C:\Program Files (x86)\a5v12\MDBFiles\]*.

figure.title: The MDBFiles folder in the Alpha Anyhwere installation directory is where you can find the Northwind Access database

step.description: Select the *[Northwind.mdb]* file and copy the file to a directory in your Users directory. Your Users directory is typically located in *[bold:C:\Users\Your_Windows_UserName]*.

Next, create a connection string to the Northwind database by creating a new AlphaDAO Connection. From the Web Projects Control Panel, select *[ui:[ManageConnStr] Manage Connection Strings]* > *[ui:Alpha DAO Connection strings]* from the *[ui:Edit]* menu to create a new connecton string.

figure.title: Open the AlphaDAO Connections dialog.
The AlphaDAO Connections Dialog.

step.description: Click the *[ui:New]* button to create a new connection string. Type in "Northwind" for the *[ui:Connection Name]* and click the *[ui:Build]* button to construct the *[ui:Connection String]*.

figure.title: Creating a new connection to the Northwind Access database.

description.p: The Connection Type for your new connection string is "Access" and should be selected by default for new connection strings when the Create SQL Connection String dialog is opened.
For the *[ui:File Name]* option in the Create SQL Connection String dialog, navigate to where you copied the Northwind database and select the database.

figure.title: The Create SQL Connection String dialog.
Select the Northwind database you copied to the Users directory.

step.description: Verify the connection to the Northwind database is correct by clicking the "Test Connection" button. If everything is configured properly, it will display the "Success!" message.

figure.title: Success! The connection string works.

step.note: On some systems where Office 365 is installed, you may receive a *[Can't Load ODBCJI32.dll Error]* message. To fix this error, you will need to install the Microsoft Access Database Engine. You can download the Microsoft Access Database Engine Installer *[extlink:here@https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=13255]*. If the Microsoft Access Database Engine is already installed, running a 'Repair' on the engine should fix the issue.

step.description: Click *[ui:OK]* to create the Access connection string.

figure.title: The connection string dialog listing the Northwind connection

step.description: Click *[ui:OK]* to save the Northwind connection string and return to the *[ui:Alpha DAO Connections]* dialog.

Now that you have created a connection string to the Northwind database, you can start building your mobile application. Click the *[ui:Close]* button to exit the *[ui:Alpha DAO Connections]* dialog and proceed to [Part 1 - Building Basic Functionality] to start building your mobile application.

case.description: This section guides you through the process of creating a SQL Server version of the Northwind database and setting up a Server connection string to communicate with the SQL Server Northwind database.

step.description: Follow the tutorial, [Importing the Northwind Access Database into SQL Server], to create a Northwind SQL Server database. When you are finished, return to this guide and proceed to the next step.

Next, create a connection string to the Northwind SQL Server database by creating a new AlphaDAO Connection. From the Web Projects Control Panel, select *[ui:[ManageConnStr] Manage Connection Strings]* > *[ui:Alpha DAO Connection strings]* from the *[ui:Edit]* menu to create a new connecton string.

figure.title: Open the AlphaDAO Connections dialog.
The AlphaDAO Connections Dialog.

step.description: Click the *[ui:New]* button to create a new connection string. Type in "Northwind" for the *[ui:Connection Name]* and click the *[ui:Build]* button to construct the *[ui:Connection String]*.

figure.title: Creating a new connection to the Northwind SQL Server database.

step.description: Test the connection by clicking the *[ui:Test Connection]* button. You should see a success message. If you receive an error message, verify the *[ui:Version]*, *[ui:Server]*, *[ui:Port]* and *[ui:Credentials]* are correct.

figure.title: Success! The SQL Server connection works.

step.description: Click the *[ui:Refresh]* button to populate the *[ui:Database]* dropdown box. Select the *[Northwind]* from the list of options. Click *[ui:OK]* to create the SQL Server connection string.

figure.title: Configuring SQL Server connection string. This is image shows a configuration for connecting to a SQL Server Express instance. The Northwind database in this SQL Server instance is named "northwindSQLServer".

step.description: Click *[ui:OK]* to save the new Northwind connection string.

figure.title: Click OK to save the Northwind connection string.

step.description: Now that you have created a connection string to the Northwind database, you can start building your mobile application. Click the *[ui:Close]* button to exit the *[ui:Alpha DAO Connections]* dialog and proceed to [Part 1 - Building Basic Functionality] to start building your mobile application.

case.title: Build a MySQL Connection String
case.description: This section guides you through creating a MySQL version of the Northwind database and setting up a connection string to communicate with the MySQL Northwind database.

step.description: Download *[extlink:northwindmysql.zip@http://downloads.alphasoftware.com/a5v12Download/northwindmysql.zip]* and unzip the file. This zip file contains a self-contained file of the MySQL Northwind database.

figure.title: Contents of the northwindysql.zip archive.

step.description: Import the self-contained Northwind database into MySQL. You can find instructions *[extlink:here@https://dev.mysql.com/doc/workbench/en/wb-admin-export-import-management.html#wb-mysql-connections-navigator-management-data-import-restore]* for using MySQL Workbench to Import the database. Use the "Import from Self-Contained File" option for the Data Import.

figure.title: Doing a Data Import using MySQL Workbench

step.note: *[Backup any existing MySQL databases]* before importing the Northwind database.
step.warning: *[There is no schema specified in the northwindmysql.sql file.]* You must specify the target schema, otherwise the tables will be imported into the active schema. *[This may result in data being overwritten]* if the active schema contains table names matching tables in the Northwind database!

step.description: Next, create a connection string to the Northwind MySQL dataase by creating a new AlphaDAO Connection. From the Web Projects Control Panel, select *[ui:[ManageConnStr] Manage Connection Strings]* > *[ui:Alpha DAO Connection strings]* from the *[ui:Edit]* menu to create a new connecton string.

figure.title: Open the AlphaDAO Connections dialog.
The AlphaDAO Connections Dialog.

step.description: Click the *[ui:New]* button to create a new connection string. Type in "Northwind" for the *[ui:Connection Name]* and click the *[ui:Build]* button to construct the *[ui:Connection String]*.

figure.title: Creating a new connection to the Northwind MySQL database.
The Create SQL Connection String dialog.

step.description: The *[ui:Connection Type]* defaults to "Access". However, you are building a connection string for a MySQL database. Click the [...] button to change the *[ui:Connection Type]*. Select *[MySQL]* from the list of options in the *[ui:Select an API]* window and click *[ui:OK]*.

figure.title: Select MySQL to change the Connection Type.
The Creat SQL Connection String dialog Options for a "MySQL" Connection Type.

step.description: Next, you must configure the *[ui:Options]* for the connection. For *[ui:Hostname]*, enter "localhost".
Enter *[ui:Port]* number. If you used the default port number for your MySQL install, the port should be "3306".
Enter the *[ui:User]* for accesing the MySQL database. On your development machine, this can be "root" or a user account you create.

Click the *[ui:Close]* button to exit the *[ui:Alpha DAO Connections]* dialog and proceed to [Part 1 - Building Basic Functionality] to start building your mobile application.

description.p: In Alpha Anywhere, there are two approaches you can use to build your application: Layout First or Functionality First.

The Layout First approach involves building the shell of the application's layout, adding all the navigation buttons and layout elements with temporary data or placeholder methods, if they are needed. Once the shell looks like the end product, the CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) features are built and hooked into the interface.

Functionality First approach focuses on getting CRUD features working with a rudimentary interface. After this core functionality is built, the interface is added, including creating any additional navigation necessary for using the app in a mobile environment.

You will use a *[Functionality First]* approach in this guide. You will create a *[List control]* with a *[Detail View]* for editing data and *[Search Part]* for retrieving the records of interest from the data source. The List control is the core building block of any Alpha Anywhere mobile app. It handles displaying records from a database and tracking any changes to that data. The Detail View is an interface for creating, editing, and deleting records in a List control. The Search Part is used to select the records of interest from the data source that will populate the List control.
By the end of Part 1, you will have a fully functional app that could be deployed as a web application, shown in the image below.

figure.title: Part 1 - Building Basic Functionality

section.title: Lesson 2: Adding a New List Control
section.description: [Download Component for Part 1 Lesson 2]

The List Control is one of the core building blocks in most mobile applications. Using the *[ui:[ListGenie]List Control - Quick Setup Genie]*, you will create a List with a Detail View and Search part for interacting with the Customers table in the Northwind database.

step.description: The interface for the UX Component is designed on the *[ui:[UXControls] Controls]* pane. Insert a new List control into the UX Component by clicking *[ui:[ListCtrl] [List]]*

figure.title: Insert a new List Control

step.description: When a control is inserted into the component, Alpha Anywhere presents you with the option to insert multiple controls at once. The application you are building only needs one List control. If it is not selected, choose *[ui:Create a new Single Control]* and enter a *[ui:Name]* for your List. Once you have given the List a name, click the *[ui:[ListGenie]List Control - Quick Setup Genie]* button at the bottom of the *[ui:New Control]* dialog.

figure.title: Create a new List Control

section.title: Lesson 3: Connecting the List to a Database

step.description: Next, you will configure your List control to connect to the Northwind database using the connection string created earlier (See [Build a Database Connection String].) Select the [...] button for *[ui:Connection string]* to open the *[ui:Connection String]* dialog.

figure.title: The List Control - Quick Setup Genie.

step.description: In the *[ui:Connection String]* dialog, select *[ui:Use a named connection string]*. Open the list of named connection strings by clicking the *[ui:Select...]* button.

step.description: Click the [...] button for the *[ui:Table name]* property to choose the table that will be used to populate the data in the List control. Choose the *[[tbl]Customers]* table from the Northwind database.

figure.title: Select the Customers table.

description.p: Next, configure the *[ui:Field list]* property. The *[ui:Field list]* property determines what fields will be available for displaying, searching, and editing in the List. If you plan on editing table data, you must select the table's ID field must be included in the *[ui:Selected Fields]*. The ID field for the Customers table is *[CustomerID]*.
Select the *[CustomerID]*, *[CompanyName]*, *[Address]*, *[City]*, and *[Country]* fields from the Customers table and click *[ui:OK]*.

figure.title: Selecting the Fields that will be available in the List control to view and modify.
The *[ui:List Data Source Definition]* completely configured to work with the Customers table in the Northwind database.

section.title: Lesson 4: Setting Up the Detail View
section.description: Next, you will configure the List control's Detail View. The Detail View is used for editing or adding data to the Customers table in the Northwind database.

step.description: Check the *[ui:Has Detail View]* box to add a Detail View to the List control.

figure.title: Add a Detail View to the List control.

section.description: That's it! Now we'll add a Search part to the List Control so you can search the Customers table for specific records.

section.title: Lesson 5: Adding a Search Part
section.description: Now, you will add a *[ui:Search Part]* to your List control.

step.description: In the *[ui:Search Part]* Properties section, click the checkbox for *[ui:Has Search Part]*.

figure.title: Adding a *[ui:Search Part]* to the List control.

step.description: You will be creating a Keyword search part. For the *[ui:Search Part type]* property, click the [...] button and select *[ui:SingleKeywordControl]* in the *[ui:Select Search Style]* dialog and click *[ui:OK]*.

figure.title: The *[ui:Select Search Style]* dialog.

step.description: Next, select the fields to search in the List control when a seach is executed. Click the [...] button for the *[ui:Search Part fields]* property and select all of the fields and click *[ui:OK]*.

figure.title: Select all of the fields in the List control to search.

step.description: Finally, check the box for *[ui:Delay populate List till active search]*. This option indicates that the List control should not be populated with any data from the Customers table until a search is performed.

figure.title: The *[ui:Search Part]* configured to add seach capabilities for the List control.

section.title: Lesson 6: Adding Disconnected Support
section.description: The final step in setting up the List control with Detail View and Search Part is to add Disconnected support. This allows your mobile app to continue to work when a connection to the internet or network where a database may be stored is lost.

step.description: In the *[ui:Disconnected Operation]* properties, check the box for *[ui:Persist List data to Local Storage]*.

figure.title: Enabiling offline capabilities for your mobile application.

section.title: Lesson 7: Generate the Controls

step.description: Click the *[ui:OK]* button in the *[ui:List Control - Quick Setup Genie]*. This will generate all of the controls necessary for the List, Detail View, and Search Part. Your UX Component should have a list of controls similar to the ones shown in the image below:

step.description: Click the *[ui:[FileSave] Save]* button to save your UX Component.

section.title: Lesson 8: Previewing Your App
section.description: [Download Component for Part 1 Lesson 8]

description.p: The controls for the app have been created. Let's preview the app and try using it.

To preview what your application looks like, click on the *[ui:[WPreview] Working Preview]* tab located next to the *[ui:[Design] Design]* and *[ui:[LPreview] Live Preview]* tabs at the top of the *[ui:UX Builder]*.

figure.title: The Search Part, List control, and Detail View.

description.p: You should see a layout similar to the image above. On the left, you will see the Search Part and List control. The Search Part should appear above the List control. To the right of the List control, you should see several text boxes and several buttons. This is the Detail View.

The List control at this point should be empty. This is because there is no data in the List control. Remember that you enabled "Delay populate List till active search" in the List Genie. This means that no records will be available until a search is done. Let's do a search to populate the list with some data.

Type "Spain" into the Search box and click the *[ui:Search]* button. Several records should appear in the List control. When you click on a record, the Detail View, which is to the right of the List and Search Part, will be populated with data from that record. Select a record and edit it in the Detail View.

After making some edits to a record, click the *[ui:[FileSave] Save]* button to save your changes. A little yellow icon will appear next to the record in the List control indicating that it has been modified but has not been persisted to the Northwind database.

If there are any modifications to the data in the List control, you cannot perform any searches to pull data from the data source. If you tried to do a search now, say for "Germany", the Northwind database will not be searched. Instead, the records in the List control will be searched. This is done to prevent losing modifications to the data in the List control.

If you want to perform a new search to retrieve other records from the Northwind database, you'll need to synchronize the changes in the List control. To synchronize the changes back to the Northwind database, click *[ui:[FileSave] Synchronize]*.

Because disconnected application features are enabled, the List control will remember both the records in the List control and any changes you have made to those records when you exit *[ui:[WPreview] Working Preview]*. Click on the *[ui:[Design] Design]* tab and then back on the *[ui:[WPreview] Working Preview]* tab. The List control will remain populated with the data that was in it when you navigated away from *[ui:[WPreview] Working Preview]*.

figure.title: Searching for "Spain" yeilds several records in the List control.
The List control remembers not only what records were displayed but keeps track of changes to records that haven't been saved back to the Northwind database.

section.description: Now that you have the functional components of the mobile application working, let's configure the UX Component to look and feel like a mobile application.

group.title: Part 2 - Creating the Responsive Mobile Layout

section.description: All mobile applications built in Alpha Anywhere use Panels. Panels group controls into "screens" and provide the navigation between "screens" of your application. You will be adding the Panel Cards, Panel Layouts and Panel Headers and Footer that will define the flow of content in the mobile environment.

section.title: Lesson 1: Adding Panel Cards and Panel Layouts
section.description: [Download Component for Part 2 Lesson 1]

step.description: Select all of the Search Part controls in the UX Component. Click *[ui:[PCard][Panel Card]]* listed in the *[ui:Panels]* section. Click *[ui:OK]* to insert the Panel Card around the selected controls.

figure.title: Place the Search Part in a Panel Card.

step.description: Next, wrap the List control in a Panel Card. Select the List control in the Tree View and click *[ui:[PCard][Panel Card]]*. When prompted, click the *[ui:Insert Around]* button to place the List inside the Panel Card.

figure.title: Wrapping the List control in a Panel Card.

step.description: Check the *[ui:Fill container]* option so the List control will fill the Panel Card. This ensures the List control will take full advantage of the screen realestate available on the mobile device.

figure.title: Configuring a List control to Fill container.

step.description: Add a Panel Card around the Detail View the same way as you did for the Search Part. Select all the Detail View controls and click *[ui:[PCard][Panel Card]]*. Click *[ui:OK]*.

figure.title: Adding a Panel Card around the Detail View.

step.description: Now you must remove the Container controls from the UX. Select the the *[ui:[Container:CONTAINER_1]]* and *[ui:[Container End:CONTAINER_1]]* controls and delete them by clicking the [DelObj] *[ui:Delete selected objects]* UX Builder toolbar button.

figure.title: Removing CONTAINER_1.

step.description: Select the the *[ui:[Container:CONTAINER_1_2]]* and *[ui:[Container End:CONTAINER_1_2]]* controls and delete them as well by clicking the [DelObj] *[ui:Delete selected objects]* UX Builder toolbar button.

figure.title: Removing CONTAINER_1_2.

step.description: The Search Part should appear above the List control. Select PANELCARD_1 and PANELCARD_2, including all of the controls they contain and PANLELCARD_2's *[Panel Card End]* control. figure.title: Adding a Panel Layout for the entire UX Component.

section.title: Lesson 2: Adding Panel Headers and Footers
section.description: [Download Component for Part 2 Lesson 2]

Click *[ui:[Cont][Container]]* in the *[ui:Containers]* controls to open the *[ui:Insert Container]* dialog. section.title: Lesson 3: Using a Mobile Stylesheet
section.description: Now that the Panel structure and navigation has been established, the next step is to start styling the UX Component to look like a mobile application. Alpha Anywhere ships with a number of styles that allow you to build apps that look like iOS or Android appliactions in addition to some generic mobile styles.

section.title: Lesson 3-1: Chosing a New Style
section.description: [Download Component for Part 2 Lesson 3-1]

step.description: Start by changing the stylesheet used by the UX Component. On the UX Component's *[ui:[Prop]Properties]* pane, click the [...] button for the *[ui:Style name]* property to select a new style.

step.description: In the *[ui:Select Style]* dialog, choose the *[[style]iOS7]* style from the list of options and click *[ui:OK]*.

figure.title: Choosing the iOS7 style in the Select Style dialog.

section.title: Lesson 3-2: Installing the Style's Icon Fonts
section.description: [Download Component for Part 2 Lesson 3-2]

To preview this style you will need to install a few Fonts on your system. At this point, if you try to open *[ui:[WPreview]Working Preview]*, you will see several dialogs informing you that you need to install several fonts in order for your UX Component to render correctly in *[ui:[WPreview]Working Preview]*. Let's install the fonts for the *[iOS7]* style.

step.description: Open Windows Explorer and navigate to the *[CSS\iOS7]* directory in the executable folder where you installed Alpha Anywhere. This is usually *[bold:C:\Program Files (x86)\a5v12]*.

figure.title: Finding the A5_iOS7Icons.ttf file in the CSS\iOS7 directory.

step.description: Double-click the *[A5_iOS7Icons]* file with a .ttf extension. If file extensions are not configured to display, search for the *[A5_iOS7Icons]* with "TrueType" in the Type description. Windows will prompt you to install the font. Click the *[ui:Install]* button to install the font.

step.description: Once the install completes, close all windows and return to Alpha Anywhere.

Next, you need to install the *[font-awesome]* font library that ships with Alpha Anywhere. On the *[ui:Web Projects Control Panel]*, click the [FolderOpen] *[ui:Open Project Folder in Windows Explorer]* button on the toolbar.

figure.title: Opening the project directory using the Open Project Folder in Windows Explorer tool.

link.alt: The Open Project Folder in Windows Explorer toolbar button.

step.description: Navigate to the *[fonts]* folder inside the *[CSSIcons/font-awesome]* directry inside the *[css]* directory inside the project folder in Windows Explorer. Search the folder for the *[fontawesome-webfont]* file with a .ttf file extension, or if extensions are not shown, the *[fontawesome-webfont]* file with a "TrueType" Type. As you did with the *[A5_iOS7Icons]*, double-click the *[fontawesome-webfont]* TrueType file. Click the *[ui:Install]* button to install the font.

step.description: As you did with the *[A5_iOS7Icons]*, double-click the *[fontawesome-webfont]* TrueType file. Click the *[ui:Install]* button to install the font.

link.alt: The installation window for the fontawesome-webfont.ttf file.

Alpha Anywhere includes the built-in tools for simulating your application on a Mobile device. Let's enable mobile device simulation for the UX component and preview your app in *[ui:[WPreview]Working Preview]*.

Lesson 4-1: Sizing Panels
section.description: [Download Component for Part 2 Lesson 4-1]

When you previewed your app in the mobile emulator, you may have noticed that the List, Detail View, and Search Part were squished together on one screen. This is because none of the Panel Cards or Panel Layouts have any size information. Let's add some size information to the UX Component so the List, Detail View, and Search Parts are readable.

step.description: Select the *[ui:[PLayout][Panel Layout: PANELLAYOUT_1]]* control. In the *[ui:Panel Size and Dock Options]*, set the *[ui:Layout size]* to 300px.

step.description: Next, select the List's Panel Card, *[ui:[PCard][Panel Card: PANELCARD_2]]*, and set the *[ui:Minimum size]* to 300px in the *[ui:Panel Size and Dock Options]*.

figure.title: Setting the Mimium size for the List's Panel Card to 300px.

step.description: Finally, select the Detail View's Panel Card, *[ui:[PCard][Panel Card: PANELCARD_3]]*, and set the *[ui:Minimum size]* to 300px in the *[ui:Panel Size and Dock Options]*.

figure.title: Setting the Minimum size for the Detail View's Panel Card to 300px.

section.description: [Download Component for Part 2 Lesson 4-2]
Next, you will modify the Detail View buttons to use images from the UX Component's style instead of text to fit in the headers and footer of the mobile layout.

Some mobile devices have very little screen space. The Search Part can be docked, allowing the user to view the List control full screen. A button will be added that can be tapped to show the Search Part.

section.title: Lesson 5: Adding Navigation Between List and Detail View

section.description: Next, you need to add javascript to navigate to the Detail View when a record in the List control is selected. On devices with more screen space, such as an iPad, the Detail View and List will be shown side by side. However, on smaller screens, such as phones, the Detail View is hidden on another "screen". You need to add javascript to show the Detail View when a record in the List control is selected or the New Record button is clicked.

section.title: Lesson 5-1: Adding Javascript to Show the Detail View
section.description: [Download Component for Part 2 Lesson 5-1]

step.description: Open the List Builder for the List control by selecting the list and clicking the [...] button for the *[ui:List Properties]* in the *[ui:[Prop]Properties]* pane.

figure.title: Open the List Builder by clicking the [...] button for List properties.

step.description: Click the *[ui:[Events]List Events...]* button in the toolbar at the bottom of the List Builder to open the List Events Editor.

figure.title: The [Events]List Events button provides quick access to all of the Client-Side events for the List control.

step.description: Search for the onClick event by typing "click" in the *[ui:Filter]* text box.

figure.title: Use the Filter box to quickly find the event you're looking for in the List Control System Events editor.

step.description: Click the *[ui:Insert method...]* link at the bottom of the *[ui:Javascript code]* editor. This opens the *[ui:Insert Method]* dialog. The *[ui:Insert Method]* dialog lists javascript methods available for the UX Component and objects (List controls, maps, button lists, etc) in the UX Component. The placeholder, *[ui:{dialog.object}]*, represents a javascript object for the UX Component. It has methods and properties that can be utilized to interact with the interface elements in the UX Component.

figure.title: Insert Method dialog for the UX Component

step.description: To show the Detail View panel when a List control record is clicked, you need to call the *[js:{dialog.object}.panelSetActive]* method. Search for "panelSetActive" in the *[ui:Filter]* text box. Select *[{dialog.object}.panelSetActive(UXPanelName [, flagAnimate]);]* from the Method list and click *[ui:Insert]*

figure.title: Insert Method dialog for the UX Component

step.description: In the Javascript code editor, delete the text "*[js:UXPanelName [, flagAnimate]]*" from between the opening and closing parentheses for the panelSetActive method. Type a single quote (') between the parentheses to activate the autocomplete system in Alpha Anywhere. Press the "Ctrl+Down key" on the keyboard to open a popup menu of available Panel objects that can be activated using the *[js:panelSetActive]* method. You can also right-click on the text in the popup to activate the menu. Select *[PANELCARD_3]* from the list of choices to set the *[js:UXPanelName]* parameter for the *[js:panelSetActive]* method.

figure.title: Autocomplete is available for most methods in the Javascript code editor.

A dropdown menu is available for some methods, listing available controls a UX Component's method can access. Follow the instructions in the popup help for a method to access any dropdowns and genies that may be available.

step.description: For the second parameter, *[js:flagAnimate]*, type in *[js:false]*. The *[js:flagAnimate]* parameter defines whether or not an animation should be used when activating the panel. A value of *[js:false]* means that no animation will be used.

figure.title: Set the animation flag to false.

step.description: The javascript to activate the Detail View in the List control's onClick should like the code in the example below. Click *[ui:OK]* to save your changes and exit the List Builder.
Next, click the [...] button to open the editor for the New Record button's *[ui:click]* event.

figure.title: Open the Event editor for an event by clicking the [...] button.

step.description: Add code to the click event for the New Record button to navigate to the Detail View's pane when the button is clicked. There are already 2 lines of Javascript code in the button's click event. Add the same call to *[js:{dialog.object}.panelSetActive()]* at the end of the script. Click *[ui:[FileSave] Save]* to save your changes and close the Edit Event dialog.

figure.title: The Event Editor is where you can add Action Javascript, Javascript, or even Server-side Xbasic to perform actions when client-side events occur for controls in the UX Component.

Click *[ui:OK]* again to close the *[ui:Specify Image]* dialog and save your changes.

section.description: [Download Component for Part 2 Lesson 6-1]

Assign the *[ui:[[Level1]]]* placeholder to *[{CompanyName}]*
Assign the *[ui:[[Level2]]]* placeholder to *[{Address}]*
Assign the *[ui:[[Detail]]]* placeholder to *[{City} {Country}]*

{Address}
{City} {Country}
